title: historian-believes-time-is-ticking-for-tracing-selkirks-astronomical-clock
story: Former Selkirk councillor and local historian Kenneth Gunn attempts to unwind the mysteries of Selkirks clocks...THERE has been great anger and humour in almost equal measures recently in the Royal and Ancient Burgh of Selkirk about so-called improvements to the Town Hall and Market Place, which together have left Souters bewildered as to why the changes were made and who is responsible for the short-comings in what was supposed to be an upgrade to the towns heritage.The first thing that happened was at the Town Hall, which was the home of Selkirk Town Council and earlier was the Courthouse of the local Sherf, Sir Walter Scott.A huge underestimate in the costs of restoration saw Scottish Borders Council almost pound, short of the cost of repairing the actual steeple of the Grade A Listed Building.The building has been almost totally ignored since  when the Town Council, and all of Scotlandrsquos town councils, were swept away by a non-local authority system.What now has taken the place of local government is Scottish Borders Council whose neglect actually led to the enormous costs of repair.So what did they do and how did the manage to raise the extra capital to finish the works  They applied for further grants and also took an enormous amount of capital out of Selkirkrsquos Common Good Funds for something that these funds were never intended and all to pay for something which the townspeople had no say in and were not responsible for.That was the angry part but to counter that there is also the humour to record. It was decided by those in high office that the gold-plated cockerel weather vane should be re-plated and that the Selkirk Town Clock should actually be removed for repair and cleaning. That clock and its illuminated front face were well maintained over many years by local jewellers and clock repairers and in more recent times has been well maintained by Ritchies in Edinburgh without recourse to actual removal from the building.This time the entire mechanismwas lowered by jib-crane and taken on a lorry down to England for a complete overhaul. That was fine and no-one noticed as the whole building was enveloped in scaffolding and plastic sheeting.However, when it didand was re-installed in its original place all was not what it seemed.In fact it has never kept time since it was put back in the Town Hall. Sometimes it simply doesnrsquot keep time, sometimes it doesnrsquot go at all and, even worse, it goes backwards!What happened to the role of Clerk of Works in all this turmoil and who signed off the work which was then proved to be faulty in the extreme with the steeple now leaking water where it had never leaked before and with huge double front doors that after ldquorestoration couldnrsquot be opened Is Selkirk actually taking a step back in time Are our Councillors backward Who knows, but come the Common Riding morning letrsquos hope Selkirk Silver Band big drummer John Nicol has a watch that keeps good time or neither the First Drum nor the Second Drum will ever take place!But in the middle of all this confusion I have recovered another great mystery, or is it mysteries What happened to the works of Selkirkrsquos mason-astronomer James Scott who was born in Midlem in  and died in November . Who was he and how did he acquire the title mason-astronomer  We have to rely on an interesting little booklet written by Bowmont Weddell, M.A., F.E.I.S and who was headmaster of Selkirk Public School in the s when he wrote and published the pare which was printed by Walter Thomson in High Street.James Scott was born at ldquoThe Burn in Midlem and followed his father and grand-father into the building trade as a stone-mason after school at Midlem.His hobby was the repairer of clocks and from that he became a builder of time-pieces and studied not just the time of day but also the universe and how it worked and related to time and movement.James was totally self-taught but among the books and manuscripts he read was a lecture paper by the City Astronomer of Edinburgh, William Peck. The stone-mason cum clock repairer got even more interested in the stars and planets and their movements to each other and became so knowledgeable that he could predict the phases of the moon and work out on a nightly basis where its place in the heavens would be.That saw him on a journey in which he designed and built, first of all, his ldquoGreat Clock which told the time accurately while at the same time represent the solar system and the relative movements of the stars and planets around the centre-piece, the sun. Included in this masterpiece are the signs of the Zodiac and through its  spaces this Great Clock tells the time, the placings of the planets and a pointer also displays the date and the year.He developed several clocks, long before the advent of digitisation and modern technology. Some of his works were famous and his Astronomical Clock formed a centre-piece of The Scottish Natural Exhibition in Edinburgh in .The ldquoGreat Clock and his elaborate but extremely accurate ldquoJupiter Clock which spelled out the movement of Jupiter and the rest of the planets in relation to the Sun and Earth, were kept locally and by the date that the Rector of Knowepark Public School, Mr Weddell, wrote his paper in  these valuable inventions were part of the fabric of Selkirk Town Hall, in custody of the people of Selkirk as a tribute and a memorial to a one-time stone mason and self-taught astronomer and clock maker, James Scott.The question is ldquowhere are they now They are obviously parts of Selkirkrsquos heritage and Selkirkrsquos past but also a glowing tribute to what can and should be done even today by people with the right attitude to their own environment.If a tin shed half way down The Green, built as a garage, can in any way be classed as Common Good Property and of any value to the burgh, then all efforts should be involved in finding out where these inventions of James Scott, the Selkirk Mason-Architect are now.These clocks are certainly worthy of the title Common Good property.

title: expect-cues-as-sporting-greats-set-for-book-festival
story: SNOOKER legend Stephen Hendry canrsquot wait for this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival.The seven-time world champion leads a pack of sporting heroes appearing at the Melrose event next month.And he will be bringing the action from many World Championships to le as he discusses his book, Me and the Table.Hendry told us: ldquoI am really looking forward to come down to the Borders.ldquoIrsquove visited two or three times over the years to play snooker, but it has been so long since I was last there.ldquoThe book festival should be a really fun event. There are some big sporting names appearing like David Coulthard, so I am really looking forward to it.Hendryrsquos fascinating autobiography reveals the man behind the legend.lsquoMe and the Tablersquo charts a journey from an upbringing in Edinburgh to a purple patch from March  to January  when he won five titles and was unbeaten in  consecutive matches ndash a feat yet to be repeated.At just , Hendry became the youngest Scottish amateur snooker champion and just a few years later was competing with greats of the game such as Alex Higgins and Jimmy White.In , he retired after losing in the quarter-finals of the World Championship.He is now currently working with the BBC team at the Crucible in Sheffield, commentating on the Betfred World Championship.Hendry added: ldquoI suppose I have always wanted to write a book and after I retired in  I just felt like that was the right time to start.ldquoI really enjoy doing the world championships on TV ndash it is the pinnacle of our sport.ldquoIt is a high pressure event. I like doing the commentary, but I would rather be playing. I think the commentary is the next best thing.Stephen Hendry will appear on the Thursday evening in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm.Tickets are priced at pound and pound.From the peace and quiet of the Crucible, sports fans will be taken to one of the noisiest arenas with former Formula One star David Coulthard.The -year-old Scot, who was runner-up in the  Championship, will discuss his new book, The Winning Formula, in the Douglas Home Marquee on Friday evening.Coulthard raced to  victories from the starting grid of  Grand Prix during a glittering career.And since hanging up his racing gloves in  hersquos become a regular on television screens as commentator and analyst.In The Winning Formula, David opens the doors to the secretive world of F. Not quite so secret is Bob Championrsquos greatest achievement.After battling back from testicular cancer, and while still receiving treatment, he won the  Grand National with Aldaniti. His story was turned into the box office smash, Champions, and earned John Hurt several awards for playing the jockey.Bob will be in discussion with fellow horseracing legend Richard Pitman on Friday afternoon at .pm in the Douglas Home Marquee. He will discuss his amazing autobiography Irsquom Champion, Call Me Bob, which charts his early le, his path to becoming a professional jump jockey and how it felt being at the top of his game only to have it come crashing down with a le-threatening diagnosis.Richard Pitman willto the Book Festival winnerrsquos enclosure on the Saturday for his own show in the Buccleuch Marquee at .pm.The -year-old rode  winners in his career and  losers - including Crisp in the  Grand National where he was pipped to the post by Red Rum.After jockeying for  years he joined the BBC where he spent  years as an interviewer and presenter. He has also written a dozen books, many of them thrillers set in the world of horse racing.Also saddling up on Saturday is the only women winner of The Mongol Derby. Lara Prior-Palmer rode  dferent horses across the plains and deserts of Mongolia to win the epic , kilometres race in  - at the age of only .Driven by her own restlessness, stubbornness, and a lelong love of horses, she raced for seven days through extreme heat and terrying storms, catching a few hours of sleep where she could at the homes of nomadic families. Battling bouts of illness and dehydration, exhaustion and bruising falls, she found she had nothing to lose and tore through the field with her motley crew of horses.,params: .pushIn one of the Derbyrsquos most unexpected results, she became the youngest-ever champion and the first woman to win the race. Told with terric suspense and style, Rough Magic is her extraordinary story. Lara will be in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm.Arguably Gregor Townsendrsquos greatest moments in rugby came locked in a Twickenham changing room for quarter of an hour.Despite a glittering playing career, which saw him win  caps and took him to Northampton Saints, Brive, Castres, Montpellier and the Border Reivers, it is perhaps the recent Six Nations clash with England that he will be best-remembered.With England running riot and leading - after half an hour, coach Townsend masterminded rugbyrsquos greatest ever fightback to earn a - draw.He will discuss Scotlandrsquos six tries on that memorable afternoon as well reflecting on a playing career that began at Netherdale in .Gregor will be in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm on the Friday evening.Although best known for his voice these days, former international Scotland player Ian Robertson will also be talking rugby on Saturday afternoon. Having just retired after  years of commentating for the BBC he will discuss his biography, Rugby: Talking a Good Game, at the McInroy  Wood Marquee on Saturday at .pm.Tickets for all of this yearrsquos sporting greats at the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival are available from www.bordersbookfestival.org or call the Box Office on   .

title: gala-tech-firm-provides-happy-ever-after-twist-for-book-festival
story: A GALASHIELS tech firm has brought a happy ending to an unfolding story at the Borders Book Festival.Esme Biggar had secured an internship at the popular summer festival in Melrose.But the plot thickened when bosses at Harmony House didnt have enough spare equipment to allow the online whizz from Kelso to help deliver the social media strategy.And it was only after they turned to GB Technologies for help that everyone lived happily ever after.The independent communications provider was able to provide a loan of a Samsung tablet for the duration of Esmes internship.Mark Moncrieff, MD at GB Technologies, said: ldquoItrsquos great to see local youngsters being given meaningful work experience and as a long-term supporter of the Borders Book Festival, we were only too happy to lend Esme the tools needed to carry out her job effectively.As well as the social media, Esme will be assisting with a range of key tasks including programming, media launches and co-ordinating  events over the four-day festival.She told us: ldquoIrsquoll certainly be busy, but Irsquom looking forward to making a signicant dference."The Borders Book Festival is now one of the largest literary events in the country, so to gain transferable skills here, through a proper paid internship, will provide a noteworthy addition to my CV.Now in its th year, The Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival is once again bringing renowned authors, sports stars, politicians, raconteurs and TV personalities to the grounds of Harmony House Melrose from Thursday, June  to Sunday, June .Further details and information and tickets are available online at www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: payout-for-borders-bairns-under-best-start-package
story: EXPECTANT parents in the Borders have received a total pound, under a new Scottish Government initiative.applications for the Pregnancy and Baby Payment were authorised in the Borders between December ,  and February , .This payment is part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos new Best Start Grant package, with payments for low income families provided at key stages of a childrsquos development.Under the Pregnancy and Baby payment pound is provided for a first child and pound for any siblings thereafter.A total of , families across Scotland received a Scottish Government Best Start Grant Pregnancy and Baby Payment during the first three months of the schemersquos rollout.Shirley-Anne Somerville, Cabinet Secretary for Social Security, said: ldquoI am committed to making sure that every child gets the support they need to have the best start in le.ldquoThe huge take-up of this new benefit in its first three months highlights just what can be achieved when you design a service with the people who will actually use it.ldquoIn doing so, we have simplied the application process and offered multiple ways to apply.ldquoWe have found out where we need to promote the payment and who we need to work with ndash including health and childcare professionals - to make sure that people know that they are entitled.ldquoWe want to increase financial support to families, bringing equality to children across Scotland by giving them help towards a fairer start.David Wallace, Social Security Scotland Chief Executive, said: ldquoPregnancy and Baby Payment is the first payment that we launched that required people to apply.ldquoI am delighted with the take up of this so far and to see people applying from all over the country.ldquoWe are not complacent though and we will continue to promote these benefits through communications, marketing and the local face to face service that we are starting to set up to make sure that everyone who is entitled to this support knows about it and applies.ldquoThe Scottish Government sees social security as peoplersquos human right and it is part of our responsibility to deliver a service that enables people to access and exercise this right.

title: galashiels-pupils-work-set-for-new-visitor-centre
story: PUPILS at Galashiels Academy will see their work displayed at the new Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre.Five youngsters were invited to help design and stitch a  which will put up in the new pound.million building when it opens.And they were helped by an expert.Embroiderer Susie Finlayson, who worked on the Great Tapestry of Scotland, recently visited the school to offer her tips to the pupils.A spokesperson for the school said: ldquoIt was a fantastic opportunity for the pupils.ldquoOther primary schools have also been working on designs, so it will be great to see their work displayed at the visitor centre.

title: melrose-makes-a-stand-against-ash-scattering
story: COMMUNITY leaders in Melrose are writing to funeral bosses in a bid to clamp down on ash scattering near the town.Over the past few years several local beauty spots, including the Eildons, Scottrsquos View and the Rhymerrsquos Stone, have become hotspots for families spreading the cremated remains of loved ones.And, according to members of Melrose Community Council, the ash deposits are becoming a blot on the local landscape.Chairman of the group William Windram said: ldquoThe issue has been raised before about people leaving cremated remains at certain areas like the Rhymerrsquos Stone.ldquoThey are very obvious.ldquoI think it would be finepeople had scattered them, but in some cases they have dumped them there in a pile and they become sludgy.ldquoIt is a really dficult subject, because obviously people are grieving and we have to be sympathetic.ldquoWe could maybe send a letter to undertakers to encourage people to scatter the ashes more responsibly.During last Wednesdayrsquos meeting, members of the community council said there were a number of beauty spots in the area which have become popular with grieving families.Robin Chisholm added: ldquoA lot of people scatter ashes on the Eildons and on the top of the middle hill you can almost see footprints in them.Cremations have become an increasingly popular alternative to burials in recent decades.There are two crematoria in the region.But by far the busiest is Borders Crematorium, just outside of Melrose, where dozens of services take place every month.Local councillor Kevin Drumhas agreed to also raise the issue with the local authority.He said: ldquoI am sure this is not just a problem in the Melrose area.ldquoI will raise the issue with the Neighbourhood Services team.

title: peebles-pair-gearing-up-for-3000-mile-scumrun
story: TWO Peebles petrolheads are gearing for a ,-mile road rally around Europe.Later this month Christopher Philips and Martin Sterricks will head to the continent to take part in the Scumrun.The event, which has been established for more than ten years, sees competitors travel around in clapped-out cars, all in the name of charity.And the Peeblesshire pair will begin the five-day adventure in Dover on May  to help SAMH ndash a mental health support service.Each morning the details of the next destination is revealed, which could cover a region of around  miles.Chris will be participating in this event for the third time and has encouraged Martin to join the lsquoexperience of a letimersquo.Martin said: ldquoChris has previously participated in this event, but Im new to the team. Im really looking forward to the new experiences, new places to see and new challenges to explore.ldquoWe will be driving an old BMW  series, so driving in style!The pair can participate in the fundraising expedition thanks to sponsorship from many local businesses.One of the sponsors is Peebles-based cloth merchant Holland  Sherry, who have employed Martin for over seven years.They have supplied cloths and fabrics to tailors and fashion brands worldwide from their distribution warehouse in Peebles, since .David Duthie Auto Repairs Ltd, have also lent a hand. Chris is one of the businesss full time mechanics and has been in the motor trade for more than  years.Other local sponsors for the event include Calvalry Courier who are a fuel sponsor, Pentland Powder Coating who provided refurbished wheels for the car, and Forsyths Butchers of Peebles.Martin added: ldquoWe have had lots of support and help along the way and are really appreciative of everything that those concerned have done for us.ldquoItrsquos not until you do something like this, that you can fully understand and appreciate all the extra costs involved,The Scumrun was set up to raise money for much needed national childrenrsquos charities.Chris and Martin are setting up a JustGiving page to raise money for SAMH.

title: borders-broadband-speeds-lower-than-legal-requirement
story: A NEW report has found that almost half of Borders homes are getting broadband speeds below the legal minimum due to come in to force next year.The UK Government has legislated to give all households a legal right to request a decent connection, defined as one of at least  mb s.However, according to the Which  Consumer Insight Report  only  per cent of homes in the region are currently getting speeds above this target.Only six other regions in Scotlandhave slower broadband.Local MP, John Lamont , has been an outspoken critic of the broadband rollout across Scotland.He said: ldquoIt is completely unacceptable that barely a half of homes in the Borders are getting decent broadband speeds, while in some areas the figure is as high as  per cent.However, Borders MSP Christine Grahamesaid the Scottish Government has an ldquoambition to make rural Scotland one of the best connected places anywhere in Europe and contradicted the figures. She told us: ldquoThe Which  research does not fully represent the results delivered by its Digital Scotland Superfast Broadbandprogramme.ldquoA total of  per cent of premises in the Scottish Borders now have access to superfastbroadband, compared to . per cent in  and the Scottish Government has committed to making that  per cent.

title: peebles-best-kept-secret-is-finally-out-of-the-bag
story: The red curtain concealing the best kept secret in Peebles was lted last Friday evening when Andrew Napier and Natalie Stewart graced the stage as the Corner Elect and Lass for .Judging by the rapturous applause and cheers from the audience in the packed Burgh Hall for this yearrsquos Beltane principals, you could say Peebleans were happy with this yearrsquos selection.Andrew has spent his le in Peebles attending both Kingsland Primary and Peebles High School.His Beltane history is full, and perhaps the year he was dressed as a chef triggered his future career, as he trained in this profession and works in the kitchen at Coltmanrsquos Restaurant.The Cornet-elect is used to being centre stage at the annual festival, only hersquos normally wearing a frock and strutting his stuff with the YM Dancers, continuing the long tradition of cross-dressing at Beltane.A keen musician, Andrew has played the drums in the local pipe band from the age of nine to  years, before changing instruments and joining the silver band where he has played the trombone for the past three years.Speaking to the large audience, Andrew said being selected as the Cornet ldquois a dream come true.He added: ldquoI keep thinking that Irsquom going to get a knock on the door or a phone call from the committee to say theyrsquove found someone  and Irsquoll no longer be needed.ldquoUntil a few weeks ago the closest Irsquove ever come to riding a horse was being flung on the back of Auntie Susiersquos old horse, no saddle, no reins, just holding onto its mane for dear le. I can safely say I was not a fan, but thanks to the girls at Kailzie Equestrian, Irsquove been assured it isnrsquot normal and Irsquove thoroughly enjoyed learning to ride.Andrew says he is well prepared for a Scottish summer having endured rain, hail and gale force winds and sunshine, during his riding lessons.Supporting Andrew this year is Natalie Stewart, who says she is extremely honoured to be offered the role of Cornetrsquos Lass.She said she hoped to do the town proud, adding: ldquoBeltane is always something Irsquove thoroughly enjoyed throughout the years and this year I am truly speechless as I get to represent Peebles as Cornetrsquos Lass .Chairman Keith Brunton announced this yearrsquos Boundary Reader, Sally Swinney, who was unable to attend due to her commitment refereeing at the British Para Swimming Meeting in Glasgow.However, this will be Sallyrsquos third time in this position having been Boundary Reader twice before in  and . Since last taking on the privilege, she has learned the pipes and teaches chanter at Kingsland Primary School and is a member of both Melrose and District Pipes and Drums and Jedburgh Royal British Legion bands. She has marched out playing the pipes many times at the Beltane but will be best known in her role as a senior partner at the firm Blackwood  Smith.The Warden of the Cross Kirk will this year be Father Tony Lappin of St Josephrsquos Church who enjoyed his first Beltane last year.Describing his appointment as a ldquowonderful privilege", Father Lappin said he arrived in Peebles at the beginning of June last year and was encouraged by his parishioners to get involved in the festivities.ldquoI was quite amazed at the organisation of it all, but also by the wonderful sense of tradition thatrsquos been carried on for years and years.And arriving just in time for the curtain opening to be announced as Warden of Neidpath was Reverend Callum Macdougall.Rev Macdougall was in popular demand and hot-footed it to the Burch Hall following a choir concert in Eddleston.He is no stranger to the role of warden having graced the stage on three occasions as Warden of the Cross Kirk in ,  and . But this time his location and duties will be far dferent.Chairman Keith Brunton recalled Rev Macdougallrsquos ministry journey and said in  he made the ldquocorrect choice of coming to the Old Parish in Peebles.Describing the moment he was asked to take on the role of Warden of Neidpath, Rev Macdougall said: ldquoWe had locked up for the night when the doorbell went and standing on the doorstep was the chairman of the Beltane Committee and the secretary with him. I think the word I used when they issued the invitation was flabbergasted.ldquoI have a strange mix of feeling. I am deeply humbled but also immensely proud. Humbled to be standing on the same stage as the others along at the other end there, each of whom so richly deserves the honour that the Beltane Committee as accorded them, but deeply proud because I can scarcely believe that I am here among them.ldquoIn this beloved town of ours there are many people who are more deserving than I am to be up on this stage.The minister described Beltane as ldquothe jewel in the crown and said he is bursting with pride.ldquoMr Chairman, I am a mere lsquostooriefitrsquo, an imposter, an infiltrator in your midst, but I can assure you I stand here as a proud Peeblean, and with the greatest sincerity and gratitude I want to thank you and the Beltane Committee for the faith you have put in me. I will do all I can to repay your trust.And finally, crowning the Beltane Queen this year is a lady who for  years has been making and mending costumes for the children taking part in the festival.Mandi Bain will be stepping out from behind the sewing machine and heading up the Parish Church steps.After having a dficult year health-wise, Mandi describes herself as ldquowalking miracle.Following a very emotional speech which moved committee members in the Chambers Institute, Mandi managed to hold back the tears when she was sashed as the Crowning Lady moments later in the Burgh Hall.She told the cheering crowds that she was ldquoextremely honoured and humbled to be appointed. ldquoI am really looking forward to Beltane Week and I hope the sun shines for us all. Hip Hip Hooray!The question is who will Mandi be crowning on Beltane Saturday  The town of Peebles will find out on Wednesday, May , when the Queen and her court are announced.

title: ben-is-set-for-a-super-hero-summer-as-melrosian
story: MELROSE braved the cold on Friday to provide a super-hero welcome for this summerrsquos Festival Principals.Because of the biting cold winds and regular showers the Appointment Night formalities were conducted within the sheltered haven of the Ormiston Institute.But the traditional carrying of the Melrosian Elect around the ancient Market Cross still went ahead ndash with the Festival Queen and her course enduring the unseasonal freeze to offer their support.Despite the last-minute rearrangements, hundreds of well-wishers turned out to witness -year-old Ben Magowan officially inducted as Melrosian Elect for .The London-based nurse, who had grown up in Melrose from the age of one, couldnrsquot hide his excitement after being carried shoulder-high by his Right- and Left-hand men.Ben told us: ldquoWhen I was growing up, the Melrosian was like some sort of super-hero ndash I always thought something like that was out of reach.ldquoIt came as a great surprise when I was first approached, but the advice and support from the people involved with the Melrose Festival made everything a lot easier.ldquoIt was daunting at first but now I canrsquot wait.ldquoIrsquove even been back riding again and Irsquom getting fairly comfortable on the horse.ldquoFor me the summer canrsquot come quickly enough ndash Melrose Festival is going to be a magical week and Irsquom looking forward to visiting all of the other festivals as well.The  Melrosian, Harry Fletcher, takes up the role of Right-Hand Man with the  principal Russell Mackay as Left-Hand Man.Fridayrsquos Appointment Night also saw this yearrsquos Festival Queen announced as Primary  pupil Liva McGilliy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom really happy to be chosen as the Festival Queen this year.As well as the Festival Queen, her court was also introduced to the packed Ormiston Institute.Festival chairman Douglas Hardie said: ldquoEveryone in the Court is selected on merit. ldquoThey have all worked hard and are deserving of what they get.This yearrsquos Melrose Festival starts on Sunday, June .

title: schools-out-for-mary
story: WHEN the school bell rang at Kingsland Primary School last Friday, it marked the end of an era for a school secretary.It was some  years ago that Mary walked through the doors of the Peebles primary school and became the much-loved Mrs MacIntyre who helped keep the busy school running like clockwork.She wiped away tears of children after bumps and scrapes, kept many parents from losing their marbles with constant reminders of school events, and teachers didnrsquot have to worry about running low on school supplies ndash Mary had it all in hand.Her journey began at the old Kingsland School building on Rosetta Road from where she has fond memories. ldquoI remember leaving the empty office and walking with the whole school to the new Kingsland Primary where we have been for the last nine years. That gave me a lump in my throat, looking back along the line of children, staff and friends, all making our way to the new school.The new school sits proudly on top of the hill adjacent to Neidpath Road where Mary has been the friendly face that has greeted visitors to the school for nearly a decade.When asked what she loved about the job, Mary said it had been both ldquorewarding and erse. She added: ldquoNo two days are the same. I often asked lsquohow many plates can you spin at one time rsquo We deal with first aid on a daily basis and can have three or four children in at one time so it looks more like an emergency ward than an office.Although Mary was kept busy with her daily administration and reception duties, she always found time for the pupils. ldquoChildren would come into the office to show us their work, or perhaps a trophy they had won at an out of school event, she said.A special assembly was held at the school last week where the children presented Mary with a Kindle and a new bicycle. ldquoI will miss all the children, parents and colleagues, as the school has been a big part of my le for a long time.Headteacher Jacqueline Wilson told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe are sorry that Mrs MacIntyre is leaving us but we are happy for her as she has some exciting plans.ldquoMrs MacIntyre is well known and appreciated by our children and their families because she has always been the calm helpful face of the school and for that we say thank you very much.Mary is looking forward to spending quality time with husband Neil who has also just retired. She plans to spend her days golfing, dancing, travelling, gardening, helping Neil at his allotment, and of course cycling.But you wonrsquot find her ripping down the trails at Glentress, she told us: ldquoIrsquoll be sticking to the streets and cycle paths around Peebles.Schoolrsquos not quite out for summer, but it is for Mary who cycled off on her shiny new wheels ready for the next chapter in her le. And the only bell shersquoll hear ringing these days, is the one on her bicycle.

title: unearthly-stories-come-to-the-borders
story: FANS of music and unearthly stories will be able to see The Dark Carnival:Unplugged in Peebles and Galashiels this month.The intimate music and stage show uses songs and storytelling to tell the tale of newcomers to the afterle who discover that death is not actually the end.The show features Bf Smith, the lead singer of A New International, who will entertain audiences with his original compositions.The Scottish band released their first record Come to the Fabulon in  and have since risen to success, even playing at the Commonwealth Games in .Award-winning actor Robert Jack will accompany Bf as his virtuoso storyteller providing an innovative touch to the original Dark Carnival.Trained at the RSAMD in Glasgow, Robert went on to win Best Male Performance for Rhinoceros, at the Criticsrsquo Awards for Theatre in Scotland in .Following the premiere on the Isle of Eigg, the show will arrive at the Eastgate Theatre on May .And the next day, they will head over for a performance at the MacArts Centre in Galashiels.Tickets at the Eastgate will cost between pound-pound.MacArts tickets for Sunday May , cost from pound-pound.Both shows will begin at .pm.For more information visit eastgatearts events the-dark-carnival-unplugged  or ticketsource macarts

title: reston-housing-development-given-go-ahead
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has approved plans to build new homes in Reston, Berwickshire, despite strong local opposition.County Antrim-based Hagan Homes plans on building five new houses on land to the north-west of Reston Primary School.However, the plans have been met with  objections from local residents and Reston and Auchenrow Community Council, which has raised concerns over drainage, as well as the access road that heads north-west from the villagersquos Main Street.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos building and standards committee on Monday, April , councillors heard from Reston and Auchencrow Community Councilrsquos secretary Logan Inglis.He told the committee: ldquoThis is the first time application that the community council has ever objected to, even beyond the five windfarms.ldquoThis application has serious concerns to the residents of the area.ldquoWe have already highlighted concerns over services and infrastructure, as well as the poor drainage and sewerage systems.ldquoEvidence has been submitted to you of Restonrsquos recurring flooding, and the need to have a sandbag storage located in the village.ldquoWe would urge the planning committee to come and view the site so they can see the issues themselves.Appearing on behalf of Hagan Homes, Nichol Allan Swan, of Eyemouth-based Bain Swan Architects, was called upon by the committee.He told councillors: ldquoDrainage is often out of sight and out of mind but when it goes wrong it is troubling, but the accusation that these buildings will exacerbate this is not correct.ldquoThe problems occur when there is heavy rain, very heavy rain, and itrsquos basically a surface water problem. Therersquos natural field run off, from the field to the south.ldquoMost of that seems to occur to the west of the site, but wersquore going to prevent any more run off by installing a cut off drain all the way around the site which will collect the water.ldquoThis drain will be connected to a culvert which runs under the railway to the north, and eventually runs into the Eye.ldquoThe other issue is that surface water is getting into the combined sewer that serves this area, and is causing problems down stream.ldquoSome road gullies are connected into this combined sewer and are causing surcharge of the sewer and in some cases flooding.ldquoWersquove out careful design into this, and wersquore not taking surface water to the combined sewer, wersquore taking it to the culvert under the railway.ldquoIt will be taken off at a very attenuated rate, at just two litres a second, which is a very small amount of water. The culvert could take up to  litres.Following an hour-long discussion, councillors were finally able to decide that the proposals could go ahead, providing that in depth surveys were conducted into drainage and foul water flooding.The site will then be subject to planning conditions once the scale of the problem is known.Speaking in favour of approving the planning application, Kelso and District councillor Simon Mountford said: ldquoWe have to ask ourselves: do the proposals represent a suitable development  I think yes they do.ldquoAre the proposals acceptable in terms of parking and road safety  I think yes they are.ldquoI am a little concerned about industrial traffic but I feel this could be mitigated by an industrial road.Lauderdale and Melrose councillor Tom Miers told the committee: ldquoI think for me the main concern is absolutely drainage and flooding.ldquoWe need to be absolutely certain that any new development will not exacerbate any existing problems.ldquoI think it would be useful to include a condition that we require written evidence that the development will not add to the issues.ldquoIt needs to be in black and white, that according to the evidence it will not create more problems.East Berwickshire councillor Jim Fullarton said: ldquoThere must be some sort of attenuation to the drainage. If that work was done before construction starts, then that would be useful.ldquoIt would be the best option to make sure this is all in place before any work starts.Councillors voted to approve the application, with the exception of Galashiels and District councillor Sandy Aitchison, who voted against.

title: junior-choir-delights-with-anniversary-show
story: REVIEWBy Revd Pamela StrachanEddleston Junior ChoirAN exploding lsquoTreble Clefrsquo culminated an evening of joyous music from the Eddleston Parish Church Junior Choir last Friday evening, as Musical Director, Lorraine Mulholland, cut the spectacular Pintildeata cake.Baked by one of the Junior Choir mothers, Teresa Bedford, the fabulous cake was a fitting tribute to  years of this little choir bringing its vitality and exuberance to worship in the church.As well as giving regular concerts over the years, the young singers have raised money for charity, made their own CD and brought joy to the elderly in residential homes in Peebles.The choir has also been the starting point for many talented young musicians who have gone on to become accomplished young soloists, as we heard on Friday evening.The programme began with a touching performance of lsquoHumility  Appreciationrsquo from The Little Triangleand was followed by solo pieces from past choir members.After learning the piano for merely a year, young Izzy Steele gave a confident performance of two solo pieces, along with a duet of Bobby Shafto.Izzy already plays with great expression as the audience heard Bobby cheerfully setting sail but then becoming queasy with seasickness only for his spirits to lt as he heads for home once again.Very competent performances followed by both Jenner Brownand Shona Sinclairas they demonstrated how participation in the Junior Choir has fostered their talent and love of music.Jenner played lsquoRussianrsquo by Martrei Blanter, Blue Dayand Allegro Assai rd Movement from Concertino in D Major by Ferdinand Kuchler.These pieces would have been a challenge for older players, but this young violinist played with great panache.Shona Sinclair gave a similarly spirited performance on the piano with Branle de la Torche by Michael Praetorius, Shadows by Walter Carrol and the lively Scott Joplin number, The Entertainer.Rowan Steele, older sister of Izzy, delighted the audience with her performance on fiddle, with Farewell to the Glenand A Set of Shetland Reels.Rowan and Jenner then performed together on violin and fiddle with The Love of the Islesand Stomach Steinway Man, written by Ian Lowthian who was born in the Scottish Borders where he still works as a music teacher and educator.The ten young singers who currently make up the Eddleston Junior Choir produce a lsquobig soundrsquo and sing with such obvious pleasure and enthusiasm.The Lemonade Kid by Peter Fardellgave them all scope for their exuberance, as did their repeat performance of A Midsummer Nightrsquos Dream by Kane and Kane.We were treated to this at the summer concert last year and such was the choirrsquos obvious delight in performing this number, we were told they requested to sing it again.That seems to be the secret of this young choirrsquos success all the young members thoroughly enjoy the singing and performing, the rhythm and the sheer pleasure of making music.Delighted parents in the audience confirmed how much their children enjoy belonging to the choir as Lorraine Mulholland was presented with bouquets and warmly thanked by the Reverend Calum Macdougall for her  years of dedication and commitment to so many young singers in Eddleston and Peebles.The Church, parents and the Eddleston community all owe a huge debt to this inspirational Musical Director and music teacher.

title: inspirational-stories-set-for-borders-book-festival
story: INSPIRATIONAL stories will told at this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival. And very few will be as gripping as the ones of journalist Melanie Reid and jockey Bob Champion. Our reporter Callum Hodgson spoke to The Times columnist and the Grand National winner about their triumphs over tragedy.NINE years ago Melanie Reidrsquos le was turned upside down.She fell from her horse, breaking her neck and fracturing her lower back.Paralysed from the top of her chest down, she was to spend a full year in hospital ndash working towards gaining as much movement in her limbs as possible.But as a journalist, her first thought was to tell her story.ldquoI remember being in the hospital, paralysed, waiting to go in for an MRI scan, she told us.ldquoIt was then that I thought, lsquonot many people will know what it is like to be in this positionrsquo.ldquoI got my son to bring in a digital tape recorder and I began to dictate my feelings.ldquoI felt like a war correspondent at the frontline of my own body.ldquoI was on morphine, so I wasnrsquot exactly the full shilling, but I wanted to tell the story.It was then Melanie began her lsquoSpinal Columnrsquo for The Times Magazine. And, on the back of that, she wrote her book lsquoThe World I Fell Out Ofrsquo ndash which was published earlier this year.She added: ldquoThe column allowed me to write about what it was really like. I spent a year in hospital so I saw a lot of things on the spinal ward.ldquoI saw an amazing cross section of society, from drug addicts who had fallen over, to poor souls who had failed at suicide attempts.ldquoI hope, by writing this book, I can act as a mainstream voice for people living with a disability.ldquoWe are only ever two seconds away from disaster, and I hope the story puts peoplersquos lives into perspective.ldquoIt certainly did with mine. I no longer nag my children or fall out with my husband over trivial stuff.ldquoYou realise there are so much more important things in le.Melanie will be telling her story at the Borders Book Festival this June.And she is no stranger to the region.ldquoI used to stay down in Jedburgh and I was a guest at the book festival in Melrose a couple of years ago with Gregor Fisher, of Rab C Nesbitt, she added.ldquoI am absolutely honoured to be invited back, however I think it might be a little bit harder for me this time as Gregor made it so easy as he is naturally so funny.ldquoI am really looking forward to it. I had to pinch myself when I got the invite. I am just a journalist who will be appearing alongside so many incredible writers. I am in awe of them.Melanie Reid will appear on June  at .pm. Tickets cost pound and pound.Also on the bill this year, is another guest who has an inspirational tale to tell.,params: .pushJockey Bob Champion won the  Grand National on Aldaniti, while recovering from cancer.Known as racingrsquos greatest fairytale, a few years later his triumph was turned into a film.And now the jockey has released his new book lsquoIrsquom Champion, Call Me Bobrsquo, looking back on his incredible career.He told us this week: ldquoThis autobiography is my second book and I just thought it was the right time for it.ldquoIt has allowed me to talk about everything that has happened since the first one.ldquoI have been doing a lot of work on my charity the Bob Champion Cancer Trust and a lot of dferent events over the past few years.ldquoI am very excited to come to the Borders. The countryside is beautul, the people are lovely.ldquoI did one book festival a while back, so I canrsquot wait to do the one in the Borders.ldquoWe will just have to see how it goes, and hopefully people enjoy it.Bob Champion will be at the Borders Book Festival on Friday, June , at .pm. Tickets cost pound and pound.For tickets to either of the events, visit: www.bordersbookfestival.org, or call the box office on .

title: speed-cameras-to-target-selkirk-school-route
story: POLICE are set to target speeding drivers on a main school route in Selkirk until the summer holidays.Over the past two years residents along Hillside Terrace have lobbied community councillors with their concerns about vehicles being over the limit.As well as hidden driveways from several properties, the A southern entrance also passes past the towns secondary school.And the pavement which leads from the school gates to the town centre is both narrow and obstructed in places by overgrowing branches.Andy Jones, East Camera Safety Unit Manager, told us: ldquoThe Scottish Borders Road Safety Board has expressed concerns about the risk posed to vulnerable road users on this route to Selkirk High School."The failure of drivers to follow the  miles-per-hour speed limit increases the likelihood of a collision."Injuries will also be more severemotorists are travelling above the speed limit.The camera unit will be deployed to Hillside Terrace from Monday.They will check the speeds of drivers in the hour leading up to school starting as well as the hour following the final class.The checks are due to continue until Tuesday, July .Chief Inspector Stuart Reid, Local Area Commander for the Scottish Borders, said: ldquoMotorists should keep to the speed limits at all times and this is particularly important near schools."We are pleased to be working with our colleagues at the East Safety Camera Unit to ensure that motorists comply with the mph speed limit."We will monitor offences at this site andrequired, adopt an appropriate enforcement program.

title: st-abbs-set-for-wave-of-marvel-fans
story: A BORDERS coastal hamlet is preparing itself for a wave of film fans over the summer.St Abbs doubled up as Thors home of New Asgard for the blockbuster movie Avengers: Endgame two years ago.Now the all-star film has been released, to record-breaking first weekend box office takings of .billion, thousands of fans are reported to have searched for flight details to New Asgard.According to flight booking site kiwi, a signicant number of searches for the fishing village have been made since Avengers: Endgame was released.During the shooting of the blockbuster St Abbs was in lock down for several days.And the independent St Abbs Leboat Station was rebranded as lsquoNew Asgard Leboat Stationrsquo.Film-makers Marvel provided a generous donation to the leboat following filming.Scottish Borders Council even supplied new Asgard-inspired twin town signs for local to promote connections with the film.

title: swim-star-duncan-given-a-wet-welcome-to-the-borders
story: BORDERS youngsters ed into the month of May by swimming with one of the countryrsquos most successful sports stars.Duncan Scott, who won six medals at the Gold Coast Commonwealth Games spent the day with over  children on the Learn to Swim programme at Teviotdale Leisure Centre.As well as the chance to tidy up their technique, the young swimmers also got the opportunity to ask the -year-old, who takes on the role of Learn to Swim Ambassador, for his advice on training.Duncan, who was named Scottish Sportsperson of the Year , said: ldquoI had such a great day in Hawick.ldquoAfter competing in national events, itrsquos so nice to be able to come back to the grassroots and motivate those at the beginning of their swimming journey.There are already over , Borders children participating in the Learn to Swim programme ndash of them under five years old.Organisers Live Borders hope Duncans visit will act as a springboard for even more pre-school children to take part in the Learn to Swim programme.Amanda Blacklock, aquatics officer at Live Borders, said: ldquoIt was an afternoon to remember ndash therersquos no doubt about that.ldquoThe children were full of enthusiasm for the sport and they bounced out the leisure centre with photos and signatures from one of Scotlandrsquos most celebrated athletes in hand.ldquoWe now have space for more pre-schoolers to join the Learn to Swim programme so we encourage anyone whorsquos interested to come forward, learn more about the classes and book their kids in before the spaces fill up.The Learn to Swim programme teaches children of all abilities, starting from as young as early infancy.It is delivered by Live Borders, in partnership with Scottish Swimming and Scottish Water.Ally Whike, Performance director of Scottish Swimming, said: ldquoSwimming is a fantastic sport ndash but itrsquos a key le skill, too."With an estimated  percent of children unable to swim by the time they leave primary school, itrsquos crucial to roll out this National Framework for Scotland.

title: kathleen-celebrates-her-100th-birthday-with-the-melrose-community
story: SHE has been serving the community of Melrose for almost all of her adult le.On Saturday it was the towns turn to make sure Kathleen Dun was well looked after as she became Melroses latest centenarian.Kathleen, who was awarded the British Empire Medal in the early s for services to the local community, spent her th birthday with friends, family and many of the people who have taken over her mantle as ambassadors for the town.After receiving her telegram from Her Majesty The Queen, Kathleen entertained a stream of well-wishers at her Ormiston Terrace home.As well as community councillors Val Miller and William Windram, Melrosian Elect Ben Magowan, along with his Left-hand and Right-hand men, also arrived with flowers.Kathleen, whose brother Jack has been a stalwart of Melrose Rugby Club, was also visited by Greenyards President Douglas Hardie and Sevens Secretary Gordon Chisholm.Kathleens birthday celebrations will continue this weekend with a lunch party for family and friends at Burst Hotel.

title: smiles-all-round-at-the-the-regions-biggest-best-and-most-inclusive-playpark
story: THE regions most expensive playpark swung open last week.And the hundreds of children have already enjoyed the brand-new Harestanes slides, rope nets, climbing frames and roundabouts.Harestanes Countryside Visitor Centre not only has the biggest and best playpark in the South of Scotland it is also the most inclusive with many of the  items of equipment suitable for children with additional support needs - including the Bordersrsquo only wheelchair swings and an all-inclusive sensory boardwalk.The innovative, durable play equipment comes from recreation specialists Wicksteed, and features multi-sensory textures, landscaped features and safety surfacing.At the heart of the play park is an impressive Jedburgh Abbey-inspired centrepiece and pyramid tower.The pound, facility near Ancrum was unveiled with help from the local community and childrenrsquos storybook star, Badger the Mystical Mutt.Badger was invited, not only to raise awareness of dogs being welcome at Harestanes, but also due to the ethos of the illustrated books which cover issues such as disability, bullying and prejudice.Badger said: ldquoI cant wait to play on all these fantastic new facilities and then enjoy a higgledly-piggledy tower of toast in the Pooches Corner of the cafeacute."Itrsquos brilliant that well-behaved doggies are welcome at Harestanes and I hope children of all ages enjoy playing at the super new play park!The play park, managed by Live Borders, is the latest to be funded by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos poundmillion investment in new play and skate parks, pump tracks and other outdoor community facilities.Ben Lamb, Director of Operations at Live Borders, said: ldquoOur new play park offers children of all ages and abilities to have challenging and imaginative fun, in the stunning Borders countryside.ldquoWe are placing Harestanes firmly on the map as a must-visit for locals and tourists alike.Work has already got underway on Coldstreamrsquos new play park, while plans are being finalised for a new facility in Kelso.Councillor David Parker, Convener of Scottish Borders Council, said: ldquoHarestanes play park is a fantastic facility which will encourage local families to get outside and get active in a fun environment and hopefully encourage people to come to the visitor centre and the wider Scottish Borders.ldquoIn the last three years, we have opened impressive and popular new play parks in Hawick, Galashiels and Oxton."We have Coldstream and Kelso both on the horizon to open later in  and other facilities are due to be created across the Borders in the coming years.In a joint statement, local Jedburgh and District Councillors Jim Brown, Scott Hamilton and Sandy Scott, added: ldquoSince the plans were announced late last year, there has been huge excitement in the local community for the opening of the Harestanes play park and it is great to finally see hundreds of children enjoying the wide array of play equipment.ldquoWe expect Harestanes to see a boost throughout the upcoming summer and hopefully also bring more visitors to our stunning area of the Scottish Borders.The new park offers a iety of play equipment for children of all ages.And in addition, there is an agility trail, a picnic area and a toddler play garden.

title: family-launch-tiny-changes-to-remember-scott
story: THE family of Selkirk singer Scott Hutchison are marking the anniversary of his death with the launch of a mental health charity.Tiny Changes, taken from one of Scotts lyrics, will support efforts to improve mental health in children and young people.Although hugely successful with his band Frightened Rabbit and several solo projects, Scott had battled depression for many years before finally taking his own le during the early hours of May  last year, aged just .Scotts parents, Ron and Marion, along with his brothers, Neil and Grant, launched Tiny Changes this week.In a statement, the Hutchison family said: "Our beloved brother and son Scott Hutchison was born in Edinburgh in ."He took his own le in Queensferry in ."In those  and a half years, Scotts impact was far reaching and felt by many people."Through his music and art he made many thousands of tiny changes and encouraged other people around the world to do the same."The honesty of his lyrics and openness about his own mental health inspired people in all walks of le."It is a legacy that should be continued and nourished."Scott, along with brother Grant and fellow Frightened Rabbit member Billy Kennedy, grew up in Selkirk playing in several bands.It was only after Scott relocated to Glasgow to study illustration at the School of Art that Frightened Rabbit was formed and both Grant and Billy followed him along the M.They went onto release five hugely successful albums and gained a huge fan base around the world, particularly at home and in America.Since Scotts death there has been a huge outpouring of grief with tributes performed by some of the biggest names in indie and alt-folk music.Scotts story has also inspired many to openly talk about their own mental health issues.And it is hoped that inspiration will continue with Tiny Changes.The family statement said: "Whether they knew him personally, through his music and art, or through the interviews he gave on deeply personal matters, so many people have been profoundly affected by Scottrsquos le."Mental health, and young peoplersquos mental health in particular, was a cause close to Scottrsquos heart."He often spoke openly of his own struggles as an anxious child, even naming his band Frightened Rabbit after a nickname given to him by his Mum."Tragically, the weight of his ill health became too great for him to carry as an adult."We want to continue the legacy that Scott built. To channel the energy he generated in people all over the world into positive action on mental health among young people and to make tiny changes to Earth.The objectives of Tiny Changes are to raise awareness about children and young peoplersquos mental health issues, to advance understanding of the root causes of mental ill health, to support and promote initiatives that provide help to children and young people impacted by mental health problems, and to influence mental health policy and practice.Statistics show that one-in-five adolescents are affected by mental health issues.The Hutchison family statement added: ldquoThe charity has at its heart a passion for changing how young people in Scotland are affected by mental health issues."We want to see a Scotland where young people are listened to when they talk about their mental health."Where young people can access the support they need, when they need it."A country where young people are feeling better, not worse. And where youth mental health issues do not prevent people from fulfilling their potential as adults.

title: far-out-pupils-make-border-telegraph-headlines
story: THE Bordercreated a dferent kind of head-line last week after coming to the rescue of a local school.St Marys in Melrose was hosting  children for the Far Out Challenge.The teams of five from  dferent primary schools faced a day of art, drama and sporting challenges.But organisers were short of materials for the newspaper-hat making challenge - until we offered a few bundles of back-copy editions.Last Saturdays event was sponsored by Laser Vision.And following the many challenges set to the five-pupil teams, which included paper-hat making, wall-climbing, orienteering, zorbs and drama, Longbridge Towers were named winners with Melrose Primary runners-up.Debbie Wood, who is head of Art at St Marys, told us: "Lots of fun was had whilst new friendships were being formed."Regardless of winning there were  slightly tired children at the end of the day beaming as they left St Maryrsquos."

title: a72-driver-caught-writing-notes-at-the-wheel
story: A SHEEP farmer was spotted by police writing on paper against the steering wheel of the vehicle she was driving, Selkirk Sherf Court has been told.Officers followed Hazel Brown and observed the vehicle swerving and unable to hold a steady line and even crossing into the opposite carriageway.The -year-old of Temple, near Gorebridge, pleaded guilty to a charge of careless driving on the A road east of Peebles on January .Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said officers stopped the vehicle and found a large marker pen with the top removed with paperwork underneath.He said she had been offered a fixed penalty of three penalty points and a pound fine but she had not responded.Defence lawyer Greg McDonnel said his client had forgot to make the payment.Sherf David Hall fined her pound and imposed three penalty points on her licence.

title: emergency-services-race-to-ettrick-valley-following-forestry-accident
story: A FORESTRY worker has sustained a serious leg injury following an accident this morning in the Ettrick Valley.Police, ambulance and fire crews were called to the remote hillside just before am.And mountain rescue teams were also mobilised due to the location.A spokesperson for Police Scotland said: "Police in the Borders responded to a hillside in the Ettrick area following a report that a man had fallen and sustained a serious injury to his leg.ldquoThe -year-old was taken to Borders General Hospital for treatment."

title: all-inclusive-choir-has-the-keys-to-success
story: AN all-inclusive Borders choir will take to the stage next week to perform at a major awards ceremony.The Keys to Le Choir has been invited to perform at the Scottish Learning Disability Awards within the Sheraton Hotel in Edinburgh next Friday.Comprised of people with a learning disability, the choir is named after Scotlands strategy for supporting the learning impaired to have great lives - The Keys to Le.They are led by Sandy Devers from Streets Ahead, and Claire Taylor from The Richmond Fellowship Scotland.Formed in September last year, the group meets twice a month in Galashiels and Hawick and cover a wide range of songs.From the Proclaimers and Abba to numbers from the Sound of Music, everyone has their own favourites, but they also enjoy the challenge of learning something new.Musical members of all ages from across the Borders have spent the last few sessions practising for their big night on May .Sandy said: ldquoWe started the choir for people for people with a learning disability and their carers and families.ldquoWe love singing together as a group. We make everyone feel welcome and the emphasis is on fun and taking part.ldquoWe all encourage each other, and friendship is important - the group always has a break for coffee and a chat.ldquoAlthough fun is the key, there is much hard work and concentration involved in learning the music and words. It has been great to make new friends and sing together.Claire added: ldquoThe choir is delighted to have been asked to perform at the awards ceremony.ldquoThey have been working hard on songs for the event and theyrsquore very excited to be part of the occasion.ldquoMusic is a great way to bring people together and the choir has given people in the Borders with a learning disability a chance to come together, learn songs and have fun.Around  Borderers will attend the event in Edinburgh, with families, carers and support workers joining the choir members.Choir member Helen said: ldquoIm really excited about performing at the Sheraton but I am a bit nervous. We are all going to do our very best on the night and sing our hearts out.ldquoI like coming to the choir because I get to meet new people and sing great songs.Only a few months after forming, the choir held a Christmas concert at the MacArts Centre in Galashiels.And now, as well as the award ceremony, they will be performing locally at an event to celebrate Learning Disability Week on Thursday, May  at Galashiels Rugby Club.The Scottish Learning Disability Awards, organised by the Scottish Commission for Learning Disabilityprovide an opportunity to celebrate the rarely heard stories and achievements of people with learning disabilities and the people who support them on a national level.Linda Mitchell, SCLD Partnership  Development Manager said: ldquoThe Scottish Learning Disability Awards are about highlighting the talents of people with learning disabilities and The Keys to Le Choir is a perfect example of this.ldquoWe are delighted that they will be entertaining our guests at the awards and showcasing just how hard they work to deliver great performances, and the talent that people with learning disabilities in the Borders have to offer.

title: borders-gp-to-stand-in-eu-election-for-change-uk
story: A GP from Peebles is to stand for Britainrsquos newest political party in the upcoming European election.Kate Forman , who works in Selkirk, will be on the ballot paper representing Change UK on May .She told us: ldquoI have worked in the NHS for  years and am proud of our world class health service and the people who work in it.ldquoI strongly believe that we should protect our public services and ensure that they are adequately funded.ldquoI am standing in these elections as I believe that it is crucial to keep Britainrsquos voice around the table in the European Parliament.Pro-EU Change UK was formed just two months ago after several MPs left Labour and Conservatives to sit as independents. Former Tory Heidi Allen is the current acting leader, while ex-Labour MP Chuka Umunna is the partyrsquos spokesperson.Ms Forman told us: ldquoChange UK supports a Peoplersquos Vote to give the public a final say and resolve the Brexit mess and will be campaigning to remain in the European Union. I consider myself lucky to live and work in such a beautul area and to have been able to bring up my family in the Scottish Borders.ldquoI, like over  per cent of Change UK candidates, come from a non-political background as Change UK is trying to increase the ersity and range of experience of people in politics.ldquoI am delighted to have been chosen to stand in these elections.As previously reported, other Borderers standing include Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam, who is third on the list for the Conservatives Tweeddale West councillor Heather AndersonSelkirkshire councillor and executive member for roads and infrastructure, Gordon Edgaras well as former council convenor Catriona Bhatia .

title: cartoon-crackdown-comes-into-force-at-borders-primary
story: ROAD safety bosses have launched a cartoon crackdown on problem parkers at a Borders school.Andthe colourful Karen and Gary cut-outs are successful they could be appearing around other primaries in the region.The safety scheme was launched this week at Broomlands Primary School in Kelso with the primarys junior road safety officers Daisy, Elena and Emily alongside Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Safer Routes to School Team.The two cartoon characters - who have been named after the local authoritys safety officers Gary Haldane and Karen McGrath - carry the messages, Think Before You Park and Donrsquot Park on the Zig-Zag Lines.Safety officers hope the reminders will stop parents and carers illegally parking around the school gates.Karen McGrath, from Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Safer Route to School team, said: ldquoWe are delighted to work with Broomlands Primary School on the launch of this new scheme.ldquoWe hope these bollards serve as a reminder to some of parents and carers to park responsibility when dropping off or picking up their children at the school."An even better alternative would be to encourage them to walk, cycle, scooter, walk and stride.The introduction of Gary and Karen has been welcomed by school staff and pupils at Broomlands.Headteacher Michelle Matthews added: ldquoWe have a fantastic new school building here at Broomlands, but we have had some issues with parking.ldquoWe are working closely with the councilrsquos safer Routes to School team, and the parents and carers, to make sure the children can access thee school safely, and we are very pleased to trial this new scheme.

title: end of the world cycle event geared down
story: Kintyre Wheelers Cycling Club#sEnd of the Worldevent, on the weekend of May  and , had attracted some leading Scottish cyclists but across all events, on both days, there were less than two dozen entries.Entry was through the British Cycling website and EOTW was strongly promoted, by its founder, KWCC secretary Robbie Semple, at the recent Scottish Cycling Running and Outdoor Pursuits Show in Glasgow.With one Monday left to go on entries, at the KWCC committee meeting, in Campbeltown last Wednesday, it was decided to change the event from two days to Sunday only.Any entrants have been fully refunded through British Cycling.It will also be classed as a closed event, confined to KWCC members only.The confined status would mean that anyone from outwith Kintyre could still take part by paying the £ to join KWCC, which is a big discount on the EOTW entry fee.The format has not been confirmed but KWCC#s provisional plan includes a  mile time trial and a MACC Runway Rush, which is a sprint race, recently pioneered at the opening weekend of the season.The event may close with an Australian Pursuit Race ,members have any cycling left in their legs.An APR is a handicap race with the slowest away first over a shorter distance than the planned six hour endurance event.A KWCC spokesperson said: #Hopefully In the future we can look at organising something bigger.#It simply wasn’t going to be viable. The largest entry we had was  for the Saturday  mile time trial and only four competitors were from outwith the area.#However the closed to club event will be free to club members and anyone who joins will have membership till June .#There will be a practice weekend at MACC on Easter Sunday.#Mr Semple re-founded KWCC nearly two years ago. title: injury mars a tough competitive match
story: The tough competitive match between Neilston AFC and Campbeltown Pupils was abandoned, after an extremely fair first half, when winger Andrew Henderson # #Twiggy#- suffered a broken leg.With both players fully committed, the Neilston goalkeeper collided with the incoming forward, resulting in a penalty kick to the visitors.Unfortunately, Andrew had sustained a broken leg, and with the score standing at - to the home side, the Pupil#s scorer was former Son#s player Donald McCallum, the referee dispensed with the penalty and, indeed the rest of the match.The abandoned fixture will be re-scheduled to later in the season.Everyone wishes Andrew a quick and full recovery, and hopefully the ordeal won#t spoil his love of the sport.Our thanks to Neilston for their immediate response and help with the injury.Campbeltown Pupils host Hillington at Kintyre Park tomorrow with a pm kick off.

title: blustery conditions as bowls greens officially open
story: At Campbeltown Bowling Club on Saturday afternoon, president Bobby Dalziel welcomed a good crowd of players who were willing to endure the cold conditions before his we Lorraine sent the first jack straight down the Stronvaar green.She was presented with a bouquet of flowers by vice president David Brown#s two-year-old daughter, Olivia.Across town at Argyll Bowling Club, president Kenny Kerr welcomed members and wished them success for the new season, after which there was a minute#s silence in memory of those members no longer with us.The president#s we, Alison Kerr, rolled the first jack of the season and was presented with flowers by her granddaughter, Charlotte.Players enjoyed the first game of the new season, with the blustery conditions providing an added challenge.The green played well thanks to the hard work of greenkeeper Bobby Mathieson.The presidents were the winners by a narrow margin over the vice presidents. The game was followed by afternoon tea in the clubhouse.

title: letter machrihanish golf clubhouse
story: In one word Machrihanish Golf Course#s clubhouse should be #traditional# in keeping with the golf course and Machrihanish village.The proposal presented by the current committee falls short.The roof line and pitch are the angle of a Chinese pagoda. Instead of a steep Victorian pitch, the proposed roof design looks like a brim hat with the sides down.The design would look good in Hong Kong or the desert of Arizona—not in Machrihanish sited between a row of sandstone manses and the Ugadale Hotel.On the other hand, the existing pro shop is a perfect example of taste in design.The new clubhouse could copy it using reasonable construction costs, for instance two inch by six inch framing faced with a thin stone veneer similar to the cottages at the Ugadale.That is what visitors and guests want to see, a clubhouse in keeping with #Old Tom Morris#.In the name of good design, change it while you still can.Jim Gubler,Las Vegas.
